channel.title: YC Postmortem
channel.description: Real rejection stories from founders who applied to YC, Techstars, 500 Startups, and more.

item.title: No Clear Path to $100M
item.dc:creator: founder1
item.content:encoded:
Our startup was building an AI-powered code review tool. We had 500 signups and $10k MRR. But theYC partner said we didn't show a clear path to $100M revenue. They wanted to see a bigger market opportunity.
We learned that even with traction, you need to articulate a massive TAM. They weren't convinced our niche was big enough to become a billion-dollar company.
What I'd tell future applicants: Show a clear 10x better solution and prove you can capture a large market. Don't just show product traction - show market potential.
item.excerpt:encoded: Our startup was building an AI-powered code review tool. We had 500 signups and $10k MRR. But theYC partner said we didn't show a clear path to $100M revenue.

item.title: Team Was Too Junior
item.dc:creator: founder2
item.content:encoded:
We had a solid idea for a B2B SaaS platform. Our pitch deck was clean and our idea was well-validated. But the interview focused heavily on our team composition.
The partner told us our team was "too junior" - we were first-time founders without prior exits. They wanted to see experienced operators who had built and scaled companies before.
What I'd tell future applicants: Either have a co-founder with a strong background or show evidence of rapid learning and execution. Consider bringing on an advisor with domain expertise.
item.excerpt:encoded: We had a solid idea for a B2B SaaS platform. But the interview focused heavily on our team composition. The partner told us our team was "too junior".

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Team was too junior - first-time founders

item.title: Not a Big Enough Problem
item.dc:creator: founder3
item.content:encoded:
We were building a tool for freelance graphic designers to manage their invoices and contracts. It was a real pain point we understood deeply. We had 1,000 paying customers.
But theYC partner said the problem wasn't big enough. They wanted to see founders tackling problems that affected millions of people, not a niche of ~10 million freelancers.
What I'd tell future applicants: Choose a problem that affects a massive market. Even if your initial niche is smaller, show how you can expand into adjacent markets.
item.excerpt:encoded: We were building a tool for freelance graphic designers. But theYC partner said the problem wasn't big enough - they wanted problems affecting millions.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Not a big enough problem - too niche

item.title: Timing Was Off
item.dc:creator: founder4
item.content:encoded:
We were building an AI-powered legal document analyzer. The space is now hot, but when we applied, it was too early. The market wasn't ready for AI legal tools.
The partner said we were "early to the market" - a polite way of saying they'd pass. They wanted to see more market validation before investing.
What I'd tell future applicants: Timing matters. If you're too early, show why the market is about to shift. Bring data or customer signals that validate the timing.
item.excerpt:encoded: We were building an AI-powered legal document analyzer. When we applied, it was too early. The partner said we were "early to the market".

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Timing was off - too early for the market

item.title: Crowded Space with No Differentiation
item.dc:creator: founder5
item.content:encoded:
We were building a meal planning app. Seems like every startup is building something in the food space. We had 10k users but it was hard to stand out.
The partner asked "Why you and not the 50 other meal planning apps?" We didn't have a good answer. Our differentiation was weak.
What I'd tell future applicants: Know your competitors inside out. Be able to articulate exactly why you're 10x better, not just slightly better. Show defensibility.
item.excerpt:encoded: We were building a meal planning app. The partner asked "Why you and not the 50 other meal planning apps?" We didn't have a good answer.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Crowded space with no clear differentiation
